text: What would you tell someone who is new to content writing? Where would you tell them to get their first gigs? Would you recommend building a portfolio and then applying for entry level positions? Or would you recommend trying to build up their own client base? Or a mixture of both? What are the best sites to get started? Textbroker had a low barrier to entry, and I've heard mixed reviews about upwork and such. Any tips for someone getting started? I'm asking for a friend. Thanks.

elements.text: What would you tell someone who is new to content writing? Where would you tell them to get their first gigs? Would you recommend building a portfolio and then applying for entry level positions? Or would you recommend trying to build up their own client base? Or a mixture of both? What are the best sites to get started? Textbroker had a low barrier to entry, and I've heard mixed reviews about upwork and such. Any tips for someone getting started? I'm asking for a friend. Thanks.

text: What a great question! I would say be willing to write anything, especially if you're first starting out and don't quite know if you want to specialize in a certain industry or type of writing. Try and write digital and print pieces, if it's possible. I also think it's important to get some experience being a part of client meetings and to not shy away from asking for a quick meeting to talk through a project. Portfolio-building work is important, but asking for a small, nominal fee just gives you practice in those awkward negotiating skills. I  had very mixed results when I started working w/ Upwork. I had the most success becoming involved in local writing and marketing groups and making "coffee connections" that endure to this day. Good luck to your friend!

text: Not quite a marketing-specific question, but I wondered if anyone would be willing to share their experiences/advice with planning for maternity/paternity leave...with a company that doesn't officially have a policy in place. My conversations with HR have been been confusing since my company doesn't offer maternity or paternity leave, but they do offer an unlimited PTO policy. They kind of told me it was up to each department-head to find a solution that works. It's important that I take time off, but I want to be fair to my team and not ask for too much.

text: Ashly’s advice is on point. Im almost half a year into a marketing career. I second the marketing group idea. It’s how I found my current employer. But they were comfortable bringing me on bc I had pieces of experience.

elements.text: Ashly’s advice is on point. Im almost half a year into a marketing career. I second the marketing group idea. It’s how I found my current employer. But they were comfortable bringing me on bc I had pieces of experience.

text:
I would recommend trying to find ways to write in current job and/or start own personal blog (it can be about anything). I find a lot of employers/clients ask for writing samples so having an active blog is great to start with. There’s also a lot of online/print publications that accept submissions, so I would encourage looking for opportunities there.

Agree marketing/writing groups are great too!

text:
Honestly, I would start by asking just as many questions of them.

What energizes them?
What topics or types of writing do they get excited about?
Do they enjoy working with teams?
Where do they want to be in a year?
What are they good at besides writing? (project management and client skills are HUGE if they want to be self-employed)

I've seen so many different ways to break in that I shy away from a "one size fits all" when people ask me this.

For example, one of my friends has done incredible stuff with Upwork (of all things!). Truly, my jaw drops when I hear about what she's accomplished.

But her path would _not_ work for me and my strengths. Nor would her current business model.

I started by writing for my then-current employer. Then reaching out to contacts who were stretched thin and needed help. That got some entry pay, some work in my portfolio, and referrals. Eventually I transitioned to working for myself.

Now, I keep a small and consistent client load because I _hate_ doing a gazillion proposals and pitches. On the other hand, my friend is a badass at that, so it works for her.

If they can start with any existing contacts, current employer, or business owners they know, that seems to be one consistently good way to get your feet wet.

text: <@U012UL77GUT> this question breaks my heart. My advice is to take as much time as you can/need with your new baby. Your colleagues will figure it out. It’s not necessarily about what’s fair to them, although that is extremely kind of you to think about them.

elements.text: this question breaks my heart. My advice is to take as much time as you can/need with your new baby. Your colleagues will figure it out. It’s not necessarily about what’s fair to them, although that is extremely kind of you to think about them.

text: Most Americans I’ve worked with have taken 3-6 months. Here in Canada, it’s the norm to take 1 year, although I find that women in tech tend to take less than that and have their partner take the rest of the leave. Some women stretch it out to 18 months, but that is extremely rare.

elements.text: Most Americans I’ve worked with have taken 3-6 months. Here in Canada, it’s the norm to take 1 year, although I find that women in tech tend to take less than that and have their partner take the rest of the leave. Some women stretch it out to 18 months, but that is extremely rare.

text: Thanks for the solidarity, <@URAV154AV>! And the advice. I'm very disappointed in my company. We were recently acquired, and they quietly changed the maternity policy without telling anyone. I'm definitely going to take 3 months. I just hope we can come to some sort of arrangement about being paid fairly during that time. The unlimited PTO policy makes it especially confusing. Your comment has served as a good reminder that me and my family's health comes first. It's better my company knows that now rather than later haha. I hope you're staying healthy and safe in Canada :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Yes that sounds extremely frustrating! A PTO policy is not a parental leave policy.

elements.text: Yes that sounds extremely frustrating! A PTO policy is not a parental leave policy.

text:
<@U012UL77GUT> if it would be helpful to provide an industry comparison to show your company what others do, I work at a b2b tech company with about 600 employees that also has unlimited PTO. Our policy is 16 weeks fully paid for new parents (any way of adding a child to your family, and for both primary or secondary caregiver status) and I believe this cannot be combined with PTO as it is leave. We have a very active Parents Business Resource Group that has shared resources with others in tech  and I could probably share more details on our policy or connect you with someone from the group!

My hope is that you will be able to take as much time as possible with your family and your company will support that. Happy to help if at all possible.

text: Thanks, <@URB31QKM4>! That's a really good idea about the industry comparison. I just started to do a comparison of unlimited PTO policies, but your solutions is even better. Your company is slightly bigger than mine, but I'll add your company's policy to this list. Really appreciate the help.
